required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Patient Removal of Catheters After Urogynecologic Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Patient Removal of Urinary Catheters After Urogynecologic Surgery: A Randomized Non-Inferiority Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: Management of postoperative urinary retention often requires the use of indwelling catheters. The purpose of this study is to see if patient removal of catheters at home is non-inferior to standard office removal.

detailed_description.textblock: Voiding trials are a routine part of Urogynecologic surgery. Management of postoperative urinary retention often requires the use of indwelling catheters. However, patients often view the need for catheters as the worst part of their surgical experience, and follow-up voiding trials in the office utilize excess healthcare resources. Many Urology practices allow patient removal of catheters after procedures, though this has not been formally studied. The purpose of this study is to see if patient removal of catheters at home is non-inferior to standard office removal.

primary_outcome.measure: Risk of Urinary Retention in the Early Postoperative Period
primary_outcome.description: The percentage of patients who have urinary retention in the early postoperative period (failed voiding trial after discharge POD 2-5) will be measured.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of nursing calls and office visits for urinary issues in the six week postoperative period
secondary_outcome.description: Number of nursing calls and office visits for voiding issues (including catheter issues, voiding dysfunction and urinary retention) will be measured.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Home removal of catheter after surgery
arm_group.description: Patients randomized to home removal will be assigned to remove their catheters on postoperative day (POD) 2 (or if Th/F surgery, POD 4 or POD 3, respectively). They will be handed an instructional packed with visual, written and video instructions for catheter removal.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Office removal of catheter after surgery
arm_group.description: Patients randomized to office removal will be assigned to return to the office on POD 2 (or if Th/F surgery, POD 4 or POD 3, respectively) for standard nurse visit with backfill, catheter removal and voiding trial in the office.

intervention.arm_group_label: Home removal of catheter after surgery
Office removal of catheter after surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All women undergoing prolapse or anti-incontinence surgery who fail their voiding trials prior to discharge
- 18+ years old
Exclusion Criteria:
- Non-English speaking
- Pregnant
- Elevated PVR (>150 mL) or dependent upon catheterization to void pre-operatively
- Urethral bulking injection surgery
- Intra-operative complication requiring prolonged catheterization
- Unable or unwilling to remove catheter at home

patient_data.ipd_description: Deidentified individual data that supports the results will be shared beginning 9 to 36 months following publication provided the investigator who proposes to use the data has approval from an Institutional Review Board (IRB), Independent Ethics Committee (IEC), or Research Ethics Board (REB), as applicable, and executes a data use/sharing agreement with UNC.
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: Obtains approval from an Institutional Review Board (IRB), Independent Ethics Committee (IEC), or Research Ethics Board (REB), as applicable, and executes a data use/sharing agreement with UNC.
